p: Before proceeding to the details of our approach we will give a brief overview of the recent analytical advances on the vaccination problem. The simplest vaccination protocol is just to vaccinate random individuals—the Random ( R) protocol—which often serves as a baseline in the literature, see e.g. Refs. [ 9– 12]. In a seminal paper, Cohen, Havlin and ben Avraham [ 9] proposed the more effective Acquaintance ( A) vaccination. In their approach, one also starts by randomly selected individuals, but does not vaccinate these, rather, asks them to name someone they met (in such a way that contagion could occur). In an uncorrelated network, the probability of meeting a node of degree k in such an approach, is proportional to k. It is important to vaccinate high-degree nodes, not only because they have more people to spread the disease to, but also more people to get the disease from.
